text: traditional Japanese tea ceremony or
chotto is so beautiful and relaxing that
I've always wanted to recreate the same
experience at home so with the help and
guidance of my friends at tsujimoto a
family-owned Japanese tea maker
producing tea in Shizuoka since 1946 I'm
excited to be able to show you guys a
simplified version on how to make matcha
at home using traditional Japanese tea
ware and ceremonial grade tea now before
we get started let me explain some of
the traditional tea ware and equipment
that we'll be using over here we have
our cha one which is a matcha bowl a cha
one should be deep and wide enough to
have ample room for our matcha whisk to
move back and forth this particular one
is hand shaped and lacquered and it has
a nice heft to it when holding it in my
hands next we have our matcha whisk
which is called HSN it's made from
bamboo and has time tips that are used
to dissolve the matcha and produce a
nice froth now if you've just bought a
new cha son you'll want to soak it in
hot water first and that's the clean and
loosen up the tine tips just make sure
to avoid using soap or any detergents
now for our matcha we are going to be
using a ceremonial grade matcha I'm
using Sugimoto sa organic ceremonial
matcha ceremonial grade powders are made
from the most tender and young tea
leaves resulting in a smooth and
slightly sweet taste profile and because
of the quality and care put into making
ceremonial grade powders they're
typically four to ten times the cost of
matcha used for cooking and drinks the
matcha labelled for cooking and drinks
is slightly bitter and has a stronger
taste profile which makes it perfect for
cookies or making lattes next we'll need
a matcha scoop which is called a tasaku
and this is typically made from bamboo
and each scoop is made to measure
roughly a quarter gram of
a powder to clean your chest up
just wipe with a clean dry cloth and
avoid any contact with water because you
don't want any moisture to transfer over
to the matcha powder and finally
optional but highly recommended you can
also serve your matcha with a
traditional Japanese sweet called
wagashi Wagah she not only adds
sweetness to the palate to fully
appreciate the flavor of matcha just
like cheese goes well with wine but
while she is also made to reflect the
seasons for example a maple leaf for
fall or plum flower designs in the
spring in essence it's not just a
dessert its art now that we have
everything ready let's get started
start by placing your matcha bowl in
front of you take two scoops of matcha
which is roughly half a teaspoon and
carefully sift the powder into the bowl
I'm using a small sifter to help remove
some of the clumps that form using hot
water 185 degrees carefully pour in two
to three ounces of water opt for pouring
near the sides verses in the center to
prevent splashing of the matcha then
lightly and slowly whisk near the top
gradually building up to a steady and
firm back-and-forth motion to the bottom
and edges of the bowl do this until all
the matcha has dissolved and you've
developed a nice foam when you're just
about done slow down and lighten the
movement to ensure there are no large
bubbles forming at the top then lift and
remove the whisk from the center
serve your tea with the optional
Japanese sweet then finish with your
freshly made bachi now traditionally
it's recommended to enjoy your matcha in
two to three and a half sips
with the last half sip being a slurp
indicating your fondness of the drink
and I personally skip that step when
you're done enjoy your matcha and your
moment of relaxation cleaning should be
just as enjoyable for additional hot
water into your empty matcha bowl and
clean both the bowl and the chastened by
whisking the hot water then discard the
water and wipe your Chou on dry let your
whisk dry naturally on a matcha whisk
stack wipe your much a scoop with a
clean dry cloth then you're done now if
the traditional whisk is too much for
you you can always use a handheld
frother which is fairly inexpensive and
will also whisk the matcha quickly for
you but I always feel like there's
something special about taking the time
to do this by hand the old fashioned way
now if you guys are interested in
learning more about Sugimoto and their
products i'll leave links in the video
description below I'm angel I hope you
guys enjoyed this matcha tutorial give
me a thumbs up if you did letting me
know that you guys love matcha - and you
want to see more machchar recipes until
then don't forget to subscribe to my
channel
angel Wong's kitchen for more Asia
recipes made simple and fun I'll see you
guys soon bye
you
